Voting FAQ

Something big just changed in my life. How do I keep voting?

Sometimes life can get in the way of voting. Here are some of the most common barriers to keeping your voting streak going and how to overcome them.

You just moved

If you are new to Travis County, you can register to vote in Travis County by mail or in person. If you just moved within Travis County, you can update your voter registration online. You’ll need to have your driver’s license, social security number, and current voter certificate handy.

You just changed your name

For this update, you can use the same online registration update process that you use to change your address. Have your driver’s license, social security number, and current voter certificate handy.

You’ve never voted but want to start

The first step is to register to vote. You can do this by filling out a form and mailing it in, or register in person. Come back and tell us which county and precinct you are in after you register, and we’ll help you get to the polls!

You are going to be out of the country temporarily during an entire election

You can vote by mail, but must request a ballot (by mail, fax, or in person) no earlier than 60 days before a given election and no later than 9 days before the election. A completed ballot mailed from within the U.S. must be received by 7:00 p.m. on election day, or 5 days after election day if from overseas.
